case_name: Thakur Manmohan Deo and Tikaitni Faldani Kumari v. State of Bihar

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 273 and 274 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 273 and 274 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeals from Patna High Court judgment and order dated December 10, 1954 in Appeals from Original Decree Nos. 309 and 310 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated December 10, 1954, of the Patna High Court in Appeals from Original Decree Nos. 309 and 310 of 1954.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on September 19, 1960 by K. DAS J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. September 19. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS J.-These two appeals

facts.text: Certificate granted by Patna High Court for appeals to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals on a certificate granted by the High Court of Patna are from the judgment and decree of the said High Court dated December 10, 1954.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed two appeals arising from Title Suit No. 42 of 1950 and Title Suit No. 23 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: By the said judgment and decree the High Court dismissed two appeals which arose out of two suits, Title Suit number 42 of 1950 and Title Suit No. 23 of 1952,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge of Deoghar dismissed Title Suit No. 42 of 1950 and Title Suit No. 23 of 1952 tried together.

anchor.surface_text: which were tried together and dismissed with companyts by the learned Subordinate Judge of Deoghar.

facts.text: Plaintiffs in suits are appellants: Thakur Manmohan Deo and Tikaitni Faldani Kumari.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs of those two suits are the appellants before us. One of the appellants Thakur Manmohan Deo was the holder of a ghatwali tenure companymonly known as the Rohini ghatwali,

facts.text: Thakur Manmohan Deo holder of Rohini ghatwali tenure in Deoghar subdivision, Santal Parganas district.

anchor.surface_text: One of the appellants Thakur Manmohan Deo was the holder of a ghatwali tenure companymonly known as the Rohini ghatwali, situate within the subdivision of Deoghar in the district of the Santa Parjanas.

facts.text: Tikaitni Faldani Kumari holder of Pathrole ghatwali in same subdivision.

anchor.surface_text: The other appellant Tikaitni Faldani Kumari was the holder of the Pathrole ghatwali also situate in the same sub-division.

facts.text: Both ghatwalis formerly Birbhum ghatwalis governed by Bengal Regulation XXIX of 1814.

anchor.surface_text: Both these ghatwali tenures were formerly known as Birbhum ghatwalis and were governed by Bengal Regulation XXIX of 1814.

facts.text: Bihar Land Reforms Act 1950 (Bihar Act 30 of 1950) enacted in 1950, came into force on September 25, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1950 was enacted the Bihar Land Reforms Act 1950  Bihar Act 30 of 1950 , hereinafter called the Act. The Act came into force on September 25, 1950.

facts.text: Validity of Bihar Land Reforms Act challenged in Patna High Court, held unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the Act was challenged in the Patna High Court on grounds of a violation of certain fundamental rights and the High Court held it to be unconstitutional on those grounds.

facts.text: Constitution First Amendment Act, 1951 enacted on June 18, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution  First Amendment  Act, 1951, was enacted on June 18, 1951,

facts.text: Supreme Court in State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh held Act constitutional except s.4(b) and s.23(f).

anchor.surface_text: and in appeals from the decision of the Patna High Court, this Court held in The State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga  1  that the Act was number unconstitutional or void on the grounds alleged, except with regard to the provisions in s. 4 b  and s. 23 f  thereof

facts.text: Principal issue in suits: Do provisions of Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950, acquire plaintiffs' ghatwalis? If so, ultra vires?

anchor.surface_text: The principal issue in the two suits which number survives is issue number 3 which said ,Do the provisions of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950, purport to acquire the plaintiffs ghatwalis ?

facts.text: Issue decided against appellants by Subordinate Judge, upheld by Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This issue was decided against the appellants by the learned Subordinate Judge and the decision of the learned Subordinate Judge was upheld on appeal by the High Court of Patna

facts.text: Appellants contend Act does not apply to Rohini and Pathrole ghatwalis.

anchor.surface_text: The first point is one of companystruction and the appellants companytend that on a proper companystruction ,of the relevant provisions of the Act, it does number apply to ghatwali tenures like the Rohini and Pathrole ghatwalis.

facts.text: Rohini and Pathrole ghatwalis are Government ghatwalis governed by Regulation XXIX of 1814.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed before us that the Rohini and Pathrole ghatwalis are Government ghatwalis and admittedly they are governed by Regulation XXIX of 1814.

facts.text: Section 2(q) and 2(r) of Bihar Land Reforms Act define tenure and tenure-holder to include ghatwali tenure and ghatwal.

anchor.surface_text: The definition clauses  q  and  r  state in express terms that tenure includes a ghatwali tenure and, tenure- holder includes a ghatwal and the successors-in-interest of a ghatwal.

facts.text: Definitions of tenure and tenure-holder amended by Bihar Act 20 of 1954 with retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: The definition of the two expressions tenure and tenure- holder was amended by Bihar Act 20 of 1954. The amendments were made with retrospective effect

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Act applies to Government ghatwalis like Rohini and Pathrole.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it is companytended that if the provisions of the Act apply to the appellants ghatwali tenures, then the State legislature was number companypetent to enact it,

facts.text: Court holds Act within State competence under List II item 36.

anchor.surface_text: We think that in pith and substance the legislation was companyered by item 36 of List II  as it then stood  and it has numberrelation to items 1 and 2 of List I.

issues.text: Do the provisions of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950, purport to acquire the plaintiffs ghatwalis? If so, are they ultra vires in their application to such ghatwalis?

anchor.surface_text: Do the provisions of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950, purport to acquire the plaintiffs ghatwalis ? If so, are they ultra vires in their application to such ghatwalis ? This issue was decided against the appellants by the learned Subordinate Judge

issues.text: On a proper construction of the relevant provisions of the Act, does it apply to ghatwali tenures like the Rohini and Pathrole ghatwalis?

anchor.surface_text: Three main points have been urged on behalf of the appellants. The first point is one of construction and the appellants contend that on a proper construction of the relevant provisions of the Act, it does not apply to ghatwali tenures like the Rohini and Pathrole ghatwalis.

issues.text: If the provisions of the Act apply to the appellants' ghatwali tenures, was the State legislature competent to enact it, or does it relate to items 1 and 2 of the Union List (List I)?

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it is contended that if the provisions of the Act apply to the appellants ghatwali tenures, then the State legislature was not competent to enact it, because ghatwali tenures like the Rohini and Pathrole ghatwalis, were of a quasi-military nature

issues.text: Does the Act purport to repeal Bengal Regulation XXIX of 1814, or would the special law regarding such tenures not be affected by the general law?

anchor.surface_text: The third contention is that the Act does not purport to repeal Bengal Regulation XXIX of 1814 and in as much as the said Regulation deals ,With special tenures, the special law enacted with regard to such tenures would not be affected by the general law

issues.text: Are Government ghatwalis excluded from the ambit of the Act by reason of sub-s. 4 of s. 32?

anchor.surface_text: The short question before us is are Government ghatwalis excluded from the ambit of the Act by reason of sub.s. 4 of s. 32 ? Let us assume without deciding, that sub-s. 4 does not apply to ghatwali tenure.

arguments.claim: Section 23(1)(f) cannot apply to Government ghatwal as office and services continue, hence tenures excluded from Act.

arguments.claim: Crown grants do not oust legislative competence; legislature can legislate on them if within power.

anchor.surface_text: The Crown cannot deprive a legislature of its legislative authority by the mere fact that in the exercise of its prerogative it makes a grant of land within the territory over which such legislative authority exists

holdings.text: The Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 applies to Government ghatwali tenures like Rohini and Pathrole through inclusive definitions in Sections 2(q) and 2(r).

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this line of argument as correct. Where a statute says in express terms that the expression tenure includes a ghatwali tenure and the expression tenure-holder includes a ghatwal and the successors-in- interest of a ghatwal, there must be compelling reasons to cut down the amplitude of the two expressions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inclusive definitions expressly include all ghatwali tenures without distinction; legislature aware of government vs zamindari but included all; artificial extension beyond substantive meaning.

holdings.text: Even assuming Section 23(1)(f) does not apply to Government ghatwalis, it does not exclude such tenures from acquisition under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is enough to point out that assuming that the argument of the appellants is correct and cl. f of s. 23(1) does not apply, it does not necessarily follow that the appellants ghatwali tenures cannot be acquired by the State Government under s. 3 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 23 allows some deductions not to apply; other clauses a-e suffice for compensation roll; does not affect vesting under s.3.

holdings.text: Even assuming Section 32(4) does not apply to Government ghatwalis, it does not exclude such tenures from the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The short question before us is are Government ghatwalis excluded from the ambit of the Act by reason of sub-s. (4) of s. 32? Let us assume without deciding, that sub-s. (4) does not apply to ghatwali tenure. What is the result? Section 32 merely provides for the manner of payment of compensation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 32 concerns manner of payment; if sub-s.(4) inapplicable, payment under sub-s.(1); does not affect inclusion or vesting.

holdings.text: The Bihar Land Reforms Act is within State legislative competence under List II item 36; no relation to List I items 1 and 2.

anchor.surface_text: We think that in pith and substance the legislation was covered by item 36 of List II as it then stood and it has no relation to items 1 and 2 of List I.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance is transfer of estates/land reforms; ghatwali duties obsolete, no connection to defence or armed forces; follows Kameshwar Singh.

holdings.text: The Act applies to ghatwali tenures notwithstanding Bengal Regulation XXIX of 1814; no repeal required.

anchor.surface_text: The Act expressly includes all ghatwali tenures within its ambit and provides for the vesting of all rights therein absolutely in the State of Bihar on the issue of a notification under s. 3 and under s. 4 certain consequences ensue on the issue of such a notification notwithstanding anything contained in any other law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 3 and 4 provide vesting notwithstanding other laws; special/general law principle inapplicable; akin to Permanent Settlement not barring acquisition.

holdings.text: None of the three points urged by appellants has substance; provisions purport to acquire ghatwalis and are not ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that none of the three points urged on behalf of the appellants has any substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects all contentions on construction, competence, and repeal; upholds lower courts.

precedents.citation: The State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga  1

anchor.surface_text: and in appeals from the decision of the Patna High Court, this Court held in The State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga  1  that the Act was number unconstitutional or void on the grounds alleged, except with regard to the provisions in s. 4 b  and s. 23 f  thereof

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga
precedents.cited_proposition: the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 was not unconstitutional or void on the grounds alleged, except with regard to the provisions in s. 4(b) and s. 23(f)

precedents.citation: Satya Narayan Singh Satya Niranjan Chakravarti  1

anchor.surface_text: In a number of decisions of the Privy Council the nature of these tenures has been explained and in Satya Narayan Singh Satya Niranjan Chakravarti  1  Lord Sumner thus summarised the position at pages 198-199 of the report In the Santal Parganas there are for practical purposes three classes of ghatwali tenures,

precedents.case_name: Satya Narayan Singh v. Satya Niranjan Chakravarti
precedents.cited_proposition: nature and classification of ghatwali tenures into Government ghatwalis and zamindari ghatwalis; ghatwal as an office with duties performed personally or vicariously
precedents.cited_holding: In the Santal Parganas there are for practical purposes three classes of ghatwali tenures...

precedents.citation: Shib Lall Singh v. Moorad Khan  1

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that where a grant is forthcoming to a man and his heirs as ghatwal, or is to be presumed to have been made though it may have been since been lost, personal performance of the ghatwali services is number essential so long as the grantee is responsible for them and procures them to be rendered  Shib Lall Singh v. Moorad Khan  1  . So much for the ghatwal.

precedents.case_name: Shib Lall Singh v. Moorad Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: personal performance of ghatwali services is not essential so long as the grantee is responsible for them and procures them to be rendered

precedents.citation: Election Appeals number. 7 and 8 of 1958  of March 20, 1959

anchor.surface_text: Our attention has also been drawn to a later decision of the Patna High Court  Election Appeals number. 7 and 8 of 1958  of March 20, 1959, wherein a distinction was drawn  1  1952 S.C.R. 898. between acquisition and resumption of a ghatwali tenure and the argument that on the acquisition of the ghatwali tenure the office lapsed was number accepted.

precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between acquisition and resumption of a ghatwali tenure; ghatwali office does not lapse on acquisition of tenure

precedents.citation: The State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga  1

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga
precedents.cited_proposition: original cl. (f) of s. 23(1) of the Bihar Land Reforms Act was unconstitutional

precedents.citation: The State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga and Others  1

anchor.surface_text: As Lord Sumner had pointed out as far back as 1923, though ghatwali duties might be divided into police duties and quasi military duties, both classes find lost their importance and the latter were rarely if ever demanded. This Court had observed in The State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga and Others  1  The pith and substance of the legislation,

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v. Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga
precedents.cited_proposition: pith and substance of the Bihar Land Reforms Act is transference of ownership of estates to the State under entry 36 of List II
precedents.cited_holding: The pith and substance of the legislation, however, in my opinion, is the transference of ownership of estates to the State Government and falls within the ambit of legislative head entry 36 of List II.

precedents.citation: Raja Suriya Pat Singh v. The State of U. P. 2

anchor.surface_text: The point is really companyered by the decision of this Court in Raja Suriya Pat Singh v. The State of U. P. 2  where it was observed  1 1952 S.C.R. 898.  2 1952 S.C.R. 1o56, 1078-79. The Crown cannot deprive a legislature of its legislative authority by the mere fact that in the exercise of its prerogative it makes a grant of land within the territory over which such legislative authority exists

precedents.case_name: Raja Suriya Pal Singh v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Crown grant does not deprive legislature of authority to legislate on the subject; legislature can legislate on subject of Crown grant within its competence
precedents.cited_holding: The Crown cannot deprive a legislature of its legislative authority by the mere fact that in the exercise of its prerogative it makes a grant of land within the territory over which such legislative authority exists and no court can annul the enactment of a legislative body acting within the legitimate scope of its sovereign competence.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that none of the three points urged on behalf of the appellants has any substance.

outcome.relief_summary: Court rejects all three contentions of appellants and holds that Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 applies to Government ghatwali tenures

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this line of argument as correct. Where a statute says in express terms that the expression tenure includes a ghatwali tenure and the expression tenure-holder includes a ghatwal and the successors-in- interest of a ghatwal, there must be compelling reasons to cut down the amplitude of the two expressions.
For the reasons given above, we hold that none of the three points urged on behalf of the appellants has any substance.

anchor.surface_text: It is enough to point out that assuming that the argument of the appellants is correct and cl. f of s. 23(1) does not apply, it does not necessarily follow that the appellants ghatwali tenures cannot be acquired by the State Government under s. 3 of the Act.
For the reasons given above, we hold that none of the three points urged on behalf of the appellants has any substance.

anchor.surface_text: sub-s.  4  of s. 32. The short question before us is are Government ghatwalis excluded from the ambit of the Act by reason of sub.s.  4  of s. 32 ? L

anchor.surface_text: The short question before us is are Government ghatwalis excluded from the ambit of the Act by reason of sub-s. (4) of s. 32? Let us assume without deciding, that sub-s. (4) does not apply to ghatwali tenure. What is the result? Section 32 merely provides for the manner of payment of compensation.
For the reasons given above, we hold that none of the three points urged on behalf of the appellants has any substance.

anchor.surface_text: We think that in pith and substance the legislation was covered by item 36 of List II as it then stood and it has no relation to items 1 and 2 of List I.
For the reasons given above, we hold that none of the three points urged on behalf of the appellants has any substance.
